case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kolla Sreerama Murthy

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 368 and 369 of 1961 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 368 and 369 of 1961 Appeals from the judgment and decree dated June 27, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in S. A. Nos. 194 and 195 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and decree dated June 27, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in S.A. Nos. 194 and 195 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated June 27, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in S. A. Nos. 194 and 195 of 1954. N. Rajgopal Sastri and P. D. Menon, for the appellants. V. Viswanatha Satstri and T. Satyanarayana, for the respondents. 1962. April 2.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on April 2, 1962 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-These two appeals are before us by virtue of certificates of fitness granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

facts.text: State of Andhra Pradesh is the appellant in both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals are before us by virtue of certificates of fitness granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution. The State of Andhra Pradesh is the appellant in both the appeals and one Kolla Sreerama Murthy a dealer in gunnies-is the respondent in each of them

facts.text: Kolla Sreerama Murthy is the respondent, a dealer in gunnies.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Andhra Pradesh is the appellant in both the appeals and one Kolla Sreerama Murthy a dealer in gunnies-is the respondent in each of them and the point involved relates to the liability of the respondent to Sales Tax in respect of the transactions to which we shall later refer.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 368 of 1961 arises out of original suit No. 268 of 1951 in District Munsif's Court, Rajahmundry for refund of Rs. 2,941/7/- sales tax for 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 368 of 1961 arises out of original suit No. 268 of 1951 in the file of the District Munsifs Court, Rajahmundry by the respondent for setting aside an assessment and obtain refund of a sum of Rs. 2,941/7/- which was partly the sum assessed and collected as sales-tax for the assessment year 1947-48,

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 369 of 1961 arises from similar suit for refund of Rs. 1,631/12/- for 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: while Civil Appeal No. 369 of 1961 is from a similar suit praying for identical reliefs in respect of the year 1946-47, the amount of which refund was sought however being Rs. 1,631/12/-. The basis of the suits briefly was that the transactions whose turnover was included in his assessment,

facts.text: Both suits decreed by District Munsif, affirmed by Subordinate Judge of Rajahmundry on appeal by State, and by Andhra Pradesh High Court on further appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Both the suits were decreed by the District Munsif-a decision which was affirmed by the Subordinate Judge of Rajahmundry on appeal by the State and by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh on further appeal also by the State. It is from these two judgments and decrees in the two second appeals that the present appeals have been brought.

facts.text: Respondent was a dealer under Madras General Sales Tax Act, carrying on business of buying or selling goods.

anchor.surface_text: It was common ground that the respondent was a dealer within the Madras Sales Tax Act which for convenience we shall call the Act being a person who carries on the business of buying or selling goods, and that the transactions whose legal character is now in dispute were put through by him by way of business.

facts.text: Transactions were entered into by respondent by way of business.

anchor.surface_text: and that the transactions whose legal character is now in dispute were put through by him by way of business. Section 3 of the Act which is the charging section-enacts that every dealer shall pay for each year a tax on his total turnover for such year.

facts.text: Respondent dealt in gunny bags manufactured in Chittivalsa and Nellimerla Mills in Visakhapatnam District.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is, as stated earlier, a dealer in gunny bags. The gunny bags dealt with by him were those manufactured, in two mills known as Chittivalsa and Nellimerla Mills. both situated in Chittivalsa in Visakhapatnam District.

facts.text: Purchases by respondent from mills on terms of written contract on printed form.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase, by the respondent from the mills was on terms of a written contract which was on printed form. We shall set out the relevant terms of one of the sample contracts for understanding the point involved,

facts.text: Contracts entered into by brokers for respondent, sent bought-notes, Ex. A1 typical for 30,000 bags from Chittivalsa mills.

anchor.surface_text: These contracts were entered into by brokers acting for the respondent and who sent him bought-notes setting out the terms upon which the purchases had been effected from the mills, and one of these Ex. Al, filed in O.S. 268 of 1951, has been treated as typical. It recites the purchase on behalf of the respondent of 30,000 bags from the Chittivalsa mills,

facts.text: Buyer required to make deposit of Rs. 15 per bale within 24 hours, which respondent did.

anchor.surface_text: The buyer was required to make a deposit of Rs. 15, - per bale within 24 hours after the contract was handed over to him and the respondent fulfilled this requirement.

facts.text: Mills issued delivery orders after receiving part payment, handed to buyer on honoring hundi.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills having thus received a part of the purchase price, they issued delivery orders directing the delivery of goods as per the contract and these were handed over to the buyer on his honoring a hundi for the value of the goods, the buyer in this case being the respondent.

facts.text: By date of delivery orders, goods answering contract description were available in mills godown.

anchor.surface_text: It was common ground that by the date when the delivery orders were issued, there were goods answering the contract description and of quantity sufficient to comply with the relative term in the contract, in the godown of the mills wherefrom on the terms of the contract, delivery was to be effected.

facts.text: Respondent endorsed delivery orders instead of taking delivery himself.

anchor.surface_text: It was open to the buyer himself to have gone to the mills and taken delivery of the goods, but this was not done and it is the departure in this respect that has given rise, to the legal controversy involved in these appeals.

facts.text: Delivery orders passed through several hands; ultimate holder presented to mills and obtained delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Instead of taking delivery himself, the respondent and this appears to have been the practice of others as well endorsed the delivers orders and these passed through several hands before the ultimate holder of the delivery order presented it to the mills and obtained delivery of the gunnies from them.

facts.text: At each endorsement, successive endorsers collected price of bales, often including profit.

anchor.surface_text: It need hardly be stated that at each endorsement of the delivery order the price of the bales represented by the quantity specified in the delivery order would be collected by the successive endorsers which would, in most cases, include the profit, if it was a rising market.

facts.text: Lower courts held no sale of goods by respondent, only transfer of delivery orders.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge and the appellate Courts including the learned Judges of the High Court came to the conclusion that on these facts there was no sale of goods by the respondent, because the transaction so far as he was concerned consisted merely of the endorsement of the delivery order issued by the mills

facts.text: Supreme Court holds transactions were sales of goods, relying on Bayyana Bhimayya case.

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary for us to canvass in detail the argument which found favour with the Courts below by reason of the judgment of this Court in Bayyana Bhimayya versus Government of Andhra Pradesh, where the points urged in favour of the respondent were considered and repelled.

facts.text: O.S. 268 of 1951 filed on July 25, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Before concluding, however, it is necessary to refer to one matter. 0. S. 268 of 1951 was filed on July 25, 1951 and the plaint in O.S. 309 of 1951 on September 6, 1951.

facts.text: O.S. 309 of 1951 filed on September 6, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and the plaint in O.S. 309 of 1951 on September 6, 1951. Even, however, before that date, on May 15, 1951 the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 was amended by Madras Act VI of 1951

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 amended on May 15, 1951 by Act VI of 1951 adding s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: Even, however, before that date, on May 15, 1951 the Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 was amended by Madras Act VI of 1951 by which, inter alia, s. 18A was added to the parent Act.

facts.text: Delivery of goods to ultimate endorsee was effected.

anchor.surface_text: There is however no factual basis for this submission. This fact was not alleged by the respondent at any stage of the proceedings starting from the plaint in the Court of the District Munsif right up to the statement of the case in this Court
under Art. 13 3  1   c  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the transactions to whose details we shall presently refer, Which the respondent admittedly entered into, were, or were not sales of goods within the Madras General Sales Tax Act (Act IX of 1939) so as to enable the turnover represented by these sales to be brought to tax under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The only matter therefore which is in controversy between the parties is as to whether the transactions to whose details we shall presently refer, Which the respondent admittedly entered into, wore, or were number sales of goods within the Madras General Sales Tax Act  Act IX

issues.text: whether the transactions entered into by the respondent by way of endorsement of delivery orders issued by the mills constituted sales of goods by him so as to attract tax under section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the transaction involved in the successive endorsements of the delivery orders issued to the purchaser from the Mills, this Court said In so far as the third parties were concerned they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties.

issues.text: whether the suit should have been dismissed by the Courts below as not maintainable, being barred by section 18A of the Madras General Sales Tax Act.

whether on a proper construction of s. 18A ... the section had no retrospective effect and could be invoked only in the case of those assessments which were completed after the new section came into force.

if s. 18A barred even suits in respect of illegal assessments which had been completed and had become final, whether the provision was unconstitutional as violative of rights guaranteed by Art. 19(1)(f)(g).

holdings.text: The transactions entered into by the respondent by way of endorsement of delivery orders issued by the mills constituted sales of goods within the Madras General Sales Tax Act so as to attract tax under section 3 on the turnover represented by these sales.

anchor.surface_text: The only matter therefore which is in controversy between the parties is as to whether the transactions to whose details we shall presently refer, Which the respondent admittedly entered into, wore, or were not sales of goods within the Madras General Sales Tax Act (Act IX of 1939) so as to enable the turnover represented by these sales to be brought to tax under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erred; prior Supreme Court judgment in Bayyana Bhimayya considered and repelled respondent's arguments; correctness of that decision not disputed.

holdings.text: Endorsement of delivery orders constitutes a fresh transaction of sale of goods between the endorser and the endorsee, with tax payable on both the sale by the mills and the subsequent sale by the intermediate dealer.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the transaction involved in the successive endorsements of the delivery orders issued to the purchaser from the Mills, this Court said In so far as the third parties were concerned they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delivery order is a document of title to goods under Sale of Goods Act s.2(4); possessor can transfer by endorsement; two separate deliveries occur, one by mills to intermediate buyer and one by intermediate to third party.

holdings.text: The principle that title acquired by the ultimate buyer feeds back to validate previously defective titles of intermediate buyers applies to successive endorsements of delivery orders.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference could usefully be made to the decision in Butterworth v. Kingsway Motors Ltd... the title so acquired went to feed the previously defective titles of the subsequent buyers and ensured to their benefit We consider that it is this principle that forms the basis of the decision of this Court in Bayyanas case and that it would equally apply to the facts of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to Butterworth v. Kingsway Motors; forms basis of Bayyana Bhimayya and applies here as mills honour endorsements.

holdings.text: Bayyana Bhimayya is applicable and the High Court's attempt to distinguish it is incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent placed some reliance on the penultimate paragraph of the judgment in Bayyanas case where this Court referring to the judgments not under appeal stated The facts were different...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common understanding that mills would honour endorsements; no real distinction as property passes via endorsed delivery order.

holdings.text: Goods represented by the delivery orders were delivered to the ultimate endorsee.

anchor.surface_text: There is however no factual basis for this submission. This fact was not alleged by the respondent at any stage of the proceedings starting from the plaint in the Court of the District Munsif right up to the statement of the case in this Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation by respondent of non-delivery; all courts proceeded on basis of delivery to ultimate endorsee.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to pronounce on the applicability, retrospective effect, or constitutionality of section 18A as the appeals succeed on merits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: New plea raised late; decision on merits renders it unnecessary to decide.

precedents.citation: Bayyana Bhimayya versus Government of Andhra Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Bayyana Bhimayya versus Government of Andhra Pradesh 1 , where the points urged in favour of the respondent were companysidered and repelled. The companyrectness of this decision was number disputed before US. Dealing with the transaction involved in the successive endorsements of the delivery orders issued to the purchaser from the Mills, this Court said In so far as the third parties were companyserned they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be companysidered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties. A delivery order is a document of title to goods  vide S. 2 4  of the sale of Goods Act . and the possessor of such a document has the right number only to receive the goods but also to transfer it to another by endorsement or delivery.

precedents.case_name: Bayyana Bhimayya v. Government of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Successive endorsements of delivery orders constitute separate sales of goods by the endorsers to third parties, taxable under sales tax act, as delivery orders are documents of title and involve separate deliveries in law.
precedents.cited_holding: In so far as the third parties were concerned they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties. A delivery order is a document of title to goods vide S. 24 of the sale of Goods Act.

anchor.surface_text: Butterworty v. Kingsway Motors Ltd. 1 . It was a case where a hirer of a motor-car under a hire-purchase agreement under which the necessary payments of installment etc. bad number been made and so his title had number matured i.e. where the title remained in the owner  transferred the vehicle or such rights as he possessed in it, to others and the ultimate transfers paid the balance of the purchase price to the owner and thus acquired title to the motor-car. The question before the Court related to the effect of this companypletion in the title of the ultimate transferee on the legal position of the intermediate parties. Pearson J. dealing with this matter expressed himself in these terms The various purported sales all took place at times when Bowmaker, Ltd. were still the owners of the car, so that all the purported sellers in this rather long chain had numbertitle to it at the times when the purported sales were made. But on or about  1  1954 2 AU E. R. 694 July 25, 1952 Miss Rudolph acquired a good title from Bowmaker, Ltd., or, at any rate, made payment to Bowmaker, Ltd. which ext- inguished their title and induced them to relinquish any claim which they had to the car. I think that the right view is that Miss Rudolph acquired the title as between her and Bowmaker, Ltd. but I further hold on authority that the title so acquired went to feed the previously defective titles of the subsequent buyers and ensured to their benefit

precedents.cited_proposition: Title acquired by the ultimate transferee feeds back to validate and benefit the previously defective titles of intermediate transferees/sellers.
precedents.cited_holding: the title so acquired went to feed the previously defective titles of the subsequent buyers and ensured to their benefit

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the transaction involved in the successive endorsements of the delivery orders issued to the purchaser from the Mills, this Court said In so far as the third parties were concerned they had purchased the goods by payment of an extra price, and the transaction must, in law and in fact, be considered a fresh transaction of sale between the appellants and the third parties.
The result is that these appeals succeed and are allowed with costs.
